ol.li: Learn how to verify that a transformation is linear, or prove that a transformation is not linear.
Understand the relationship between linear transformations and matrix transformations.
Recipe: compute the matrix of a linear transformation.
Theorem: linear transformations and matrix transformations.
Notation: the standard coordinate vectors e_1,e_2,\ldots.
Vocabulary words: linear transformation, standard matrix, identity matrix.

introduction.p: In , we studied the geometry of matrices by regarding them as functions, i.e., by considering the associated matrix transformations. We defined some vocabulary (domain, codomain, range), and asked a number of natural questions about a transformation. For a matrix transformation, these translate into questions about matrices, which we have many tools to answer.

In this section, we make a change in perspective. Suppose that we are given a transformation that we would like to study. If we can prove that our transformation is a matrix transformation, then we can use linear algebra to study it. This raises two important questions:
How can we tell if a transformation is a matrix transformation?
If our transformation is a matrix transformation, how do we find its matrix?
For example, we saw in this that the matrix transformation T\colon\R^2\To\R^2 \qquad T(x) = \mat{0 -1; 1 0}x is a counterclockwise rotation of the plane by 90^\circ. However, we could have defined T in this way: T\colon\R^2\To\R^2 \qquad T(x) = \text{the counterclockwise rotation of $x$ by $90^\circ$}. Given this definition, it is not at all obvious that T is a matrix transformation, or what matrix it is associated to.

subsection.title: Linear Transformations: Definition
subsection.p: In this section, we introduce the class of transformations that come from matrices.

statement.p:
A linear transformation is a transformation T\colon\R^n\to\R^m satisfying
T(u + v) &= T(u) + T(v) T(cu) &= cT(u)
for all vectors u,v in \R^n and all scalars c.

subsection.p:
Matrix transformationlinearity of Let T\colon\R^n\to\R^m be a matrix transformation: T(x)=Ax for an m\times n matrix A. By this , we have
T(u + v) = A(u + v) &= Au + Av = T(u) + T(v) T(cu) = A(cu) &= cAu = cT(u)
for all vectors u,v in \R^n and all scalars c. Since a matrix transformation satisfies the two defining properties, it is a linear transformation
We will see in the next that the opposite is true: every linear transformation is a matrix transformation; we just haven't computed its matrix yet.

statement.p:
Let T\colon\R^n\to\R^m be a linear transformation. Then:
T(0)=0.
For any vectors v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k in \R^n and scalars c_1,c_2,\ldots,c_k, we have T\bigl( c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_kv_k \bigr) = c_1 T(v_1) + c_2 T(v_2) + \cdots + c_k T(v_k).

ol.li: Since 0 = -0, we have T(0) = T(-0) = -T(0) by the second defining property. The only vector w such that w=-w is the zero vector.

subsection.p: Superposition principle In engineering, the second fact is called the superposition principle; it should remind you of the distributive property. For example, T(cu + dv) = cT(u) + dT(v) for any vectors u,v and any scalars c,d. To restate the first fact:

bluebox.p: A linear transformation necessarily takes the zero vector to the zero vector.

statement.p: Define T\colon\R\to\R by T(x) = x+1. Is T a linear transformation?

solution.p: We have T(0) = 0 + 1 = 1. Since any linear transformation necessarily takes zero to zero by the above , we conclude that T is not linear (even though its graph is a line).

Note: in this case, it was not necessary to check explicitly that T does not satisfy both defining properties: since T(0)=0 is a consequence of these properties, at least one of them must not be satisfied. (In fact, this T satisfies neither.)

statement.p: Define T\colon\R^2\to\R^2 by T(x)=1.5x. Verify that T is linear.

solution.p:
We have to check the defining properties for all vectors u,v and all scalars c. In other words, we have to treat u,v, and c as unknowns. The only thing we are allowed to use is the definition of T.
T(u + v) &= 1.5(u + v) = 1.5u + 1.5v = T(u) + T(v)
T(cu) &= 1.5(cu) = c(1.5u) = cT(u).
Since T satisfies both defining properties, T is linear.
Note: we know from this that T is a matrix transformation: in fact, T(x) = \mat{1.5 0; 0 1.5}x. Since a matrix transformation is a linear transformation, this is another proof that T is linear.

statement.p: Define T\colon\R^2\to\R^2 by T(x) = \text{ the vector $x$ rotated counterclockwise by the angle $\theta$}. Verify that T is linear.

example.title: A transformation defined by a formula

statement.p: Define T\colon\R^2\to\R^3 by the formula T\vec{x y} = \vec{3x-y y x}. Verify that T is linear.

solution.p: Note: we will see in this below that T\vec{x y} = \mat{3 -1; 0 1; 1 0}\vec{x y}. Hence T is in fact a matrix transformation.

subsection.p: Linear transformationwhen defined by a formula One can show that, if a transformation is defined by formulas in the coordinates as in the above example, then the transformation is linear if and only if each coordinate is a linear expression in the variables with no constant term.

example.title: A translation
example.p: Define T\colon\R^3\to\R^3 by T(x) = x + \vec{1 2 3}. This kind of transformation is called a translation. As in a previous , this T is not linear, because T(0) is not the zero vector.

statement.p:
Verify that the following transformations from \R^2 to \R^2 are not linear:
T_1\vec{x y} = \vec{|x| y} \qquad T_2\vec{x y} = \vec{xy y} \qquad T_3\vec{x y} = \vec{2x+1 x-2y}.

solution.p:
In order to verify that a transformation T is not linear, we have to show that T does not satisfy at least one of the two defining properties. For the first, the negation of the statement T(u+v)=T(u)+T(v) for all vectors u,v is there exists at least one pair of vectors u,v such that T(u+v)
eq T(u)+T(v). In other words, it suffices to find one example of a pair of vectors u,v such that T(u+v)
eq T(u)+T(v). Likewise, for the second, the negation of the statement T(cu) = cT(u) for all vectors u and all scalars c is there exists some vector u and some scalar c such that T(cu)
eq cT(u). In other words, it suffices to find one vector u and one scalar c such that T(cu)
eq cT(u).

For the first transformation, we note that T_1\left(-\vec{1 0}\right) = T_1\vec{-1 0} = \vec{|-1| 0} = \vec{1 0} but that -T_1\vec{1 0} = -\vec{|1| 0} = -\vec{1 0} = \vec{-1 0}. Therefore, this transformation does not satisfy the second property.

For the second transformation, we note that T_2\left(2\vec{1 1}\right) = T_2\vec{2 2} = \vec{2\cdot 2 2} = \vec{4 2} but that 2T_2\vec{1 1} = 2\vec{1\cdot 1 1} = 2\vec{1 1} = \vec{2 2}. Therefore, this transformation does not satisfy the second property.
For the third transformation, we observe that T_3\vec{0 0} = \vec{2(0)+1 0-2(0)} = \vec{1 0}\neq\vec{0 0}. Since T_3 does not take the zero vector to the zero vector, it cannot be linear.

subsection.p: When deciding whether a transformation T is linear, generally the first thing to do is to check whether T(0)=0; if not, T is automatically not linear. Note however that the non-linear transformations T_1 and T_2 of the above example do take the zero vector to the zero vector.

remark.p: Find an example of a transformation that satisfies the first property of linearity but not the second.

subsection.title: The Standard Coordinate Vectors
subsection.p: In the next subsection, we will present the relationship between linear transformations and matrix transformations. Before doing so, we need the following important notation.

bluebox.title: Standard coordinate vectors
bluebox.p:
e_1,e_2,\ldotsStandard coordinate vectors The standard coordinate vectors in \R^n are the n vectors
e_1=\vec{1 0 \vdots, 0 0},\quad e_2=\vec{0 1 \vdots, 0 0},\quad\ldots,\quad e_{n-1}=\vec{0 0 \vdots, 1 0},\quad e_n=\vec{0 0 \vdots, 0 1}.
The ith entry of e_i is equal to 1, and the other entries are zero.
From now on, for the rest of the book, we will use the symbols \color{red}e_1,e_2,\ldots to denote the standard coordinate vectors.

fact.title: Multiplying a matrix by the standard coordinate vectors
fact.p:
If A is an m\times n matrix with columns v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n, then \color{red}Ae_i = v_i for each i=1,2,\ldots,n:
\mat{| | ,, |; v_1 v_2 \cdots, v_n; | | ,, |}e_i = v_i.
In other words, multiplying a matrix by e_i simply selects its ith column.

subsection.p: We will see in this below that the identity matrix is the matrix of the identity transformation.

subsection.title: The Matrix of a Linear Transformation
subsection.p: Now we can prove that every linear transformation is a matrix transformation, and we will show how to compute the matrix.

theorem.title: The matrix of a linear transformation

statement.p: Let T\colon\R^n\to\R^m be a linear transformation. Let A be the m\times n matrix A = \mat{| | ,, |; T(e_1) T(e_2) \cdots, T(e_n); | | ,, | }. Then T is the matrix transformation associated with A: that is, T(x) = Ax.

proof.p:
We suppose for simplicity that T is a transformation from \R^3 to \R^2. Let A be the matrix given in the statement of the theorem. Then
\begin{split} T\vec{x y z} \amp;= T\left( x\vec{1 0 0} + y\vec{0 1 0} + z\vec{0 0 1} \right) \\ \amp= T\bigl( xe_1 + ye_2 + ze_3 \bigr) \\ \amp= xT(e_1) + yT(e_2) + zT(e_3) \\ \amp= \mat{| | |; T(e_1) T(e_2) T(e_3); | | |}\vec{x y z}\\ \amp= A\vec{x y z}. \end{split}

subsection.p: The matrix A in the above theorem is called the standard matrix for T. The columns of A are the vectors obtained by evaluating T on the n standard coordinate vectors in \R^n. To summarize part of the theorem:

bluebox.p: Matrix transformations are the same as linear transformations.

note.title: Dictionary
note.p:
Linear transformations are the same as matrix transformations, which come from matrices. The correspondence can be summarized in the following dictionary.
\parbox{.3\linewidth}{\centering% $T\colon\R^n\to\R^m$\\ Linear transformation}% \;$\xrightarrow{\phantom{MMM}}$\; \hbox to .5\linewidth{$m\times n$ matrix \small$A = \mat{| | ,, |; T(e_1) T(e_2) \cdots, T(e_n); | | ,, | }$\hss}\\[3mm] \leavevmode \hbox to .3\linewidth{\hfil $\begin{aligned}&T\colon\R^n\to\R^m\\&T(x) = Ax\end{aligned}$\hfil}% \;$\xleftarrow{\phantom{MMM}}$\; \hbox to .5\linewidth{$m\times n$ matrix $A$\hfil}

statement.p: Define T\colon\R^2\to\R^2 by T(x)=1.5x. Find the standard matrix A for T.
Define T\colon\R^2\to\R^2 by T(x) = \text{ the vector $x$ rotated counterclockwise by the angle $\theta$}. Find the standard matrix for T.

subsection.p: We saw in the above example that the matrix for counterclockwise rotation of the plane by an angle of \theta is A = \mat{\cos\theta, -\sin\theta; \sin\theta, \cos\theta}.

example.title: A transformation defined by a formula

statement.p: Define T\colon\R^2\to\R^3 by the formula T\vec{x y} = \vec{3x-y y x}. Find the standard matrix for T.
Let T\colon\R^3\to\R^3 be the linear transformation that reflects over the xy-plane and then projects onto the yz-plane. What is the standard matrix for T?

subsection.p: Recall from this that the identity transformation is the transformation \Id_{\R^n}\colon\R^n\to\R^n defined by \Id_{\R^n}(x) = x for every vector x.

example.title: The standard matrix of the identity transformation

statement.p: Verify that the identity transformation \Id_{\R^n}\colon\R^n\to\R^n is linear, and compute its standard matrix.

solution.p: We verify the two defining properties of linear transformations. Let u,v be vectors in \R^n. Then \Id_{\R^n}(u+v) = u+v = \Id_{\R^n}(u) + \Id_{\R^n}(v). If c is a scalar, then \Id_{\R^n}(cu) = cu = c\Id_{\R^n}(u). Since \Id_{\R^n} satisfies the two defining properties, it is a linear transformation.

subsection.p: We computed in this that the matrix of the identity transform is the identity matrix: for every x in \R^n, x = \Id_{\R^n}(x) = I_nx. Therefore, I_nx=x for all vectors x: the product of the identity matrix and a vector is the same vector.
